did.abstract: Norma H. Stauffer worked as both teacher and staff member at the YWCA in Honolulu, Denver, Cleveland, Grand Rapids, Chicago, and Minneapolis from 1919 to 1963. Her papers include correspondence to family members, about daily life and work, and printed material.

bioghist.head: Biographical Note
bioghist.p: Norma H. Stauffer was born on March 8, 1897 in Cuyahoga Falls, Ohio, to Henry and Francis (Davis) Stauffer. After graduating from the University of Wisconsin she joined the staff of the YWCA working in Honolulu, Hawaii, and Denver, Cleveland, Minneapolis, and Chicago. She died June 4, 1992, in Alameda, California.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Norma H. Stauffer papers, Sophia Smith Collection, SSC-MS-00615, Smith College Special Collections, Northampton, Massachussetts.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: In depth, sometimes daily, accounts (in letters to home) of Norma's work at the YWCA during the early 1920's, into World War II and through very significant years of civil rights efforts. She held positions as teacher and staff member in Honolulu, Denver, Cleveland, Grand Rapids, Chicago, and Minneapolis from 1919 to 1963. Some printed material is included in her papers.
